summary: This is an email chain from October 2020 discussing a 2019 scanning project of 22 boxes of materials from the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The emails involve FBI personnel and federal prosecutors coordinating the scanning, noting issues like missing documents, pornographic images of young girls that were not scanned per protocol, and the handling of digital discs. The scanning was for discovery in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The investigation materials being scanned pertain to him.

persons.name: Mel
persons.context: Provides updates on the scanning progress of the Epstein investigation boxes.

events.title: Completion of scanning for Epstein investigation boxes
events.description: FBI's DocLab unit finishes scanning 22 boxes of Epstein investigation materials, noting the discovery of missing 1As and pornographic images of young girls that were not scanned per protocol.

events.title: Prior scanning by Miami Field Office
events.description: Miami Field Office had previously requested scanning of some of the Epstein investigation boxes.

events.title: Follow-up on scanning for Maxwell case discovery
events.description: Prosecutors follow up on the 2019 scanning project, asking specific questions about disc labeling and the location of unscanned pornographic images, as discovery is underway in the Maxwell case.

keyFacts: The document details a 2019 FBI project to scan 22 boxes of materials from the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, later needed for discovery in the Maxwell case.
During scanning, FBI personnel discovered pornographic images of young girls in the materials, which were not scanned per protocol due to being possible child pornography.
The scanning also revealed that some documents (1As) had gone missing from the files between 2013 and 2015 and had to be regenerated from digital copies.
Numerous digital discs were found scattered throughout the boxes; these were physically copied but not processed/extracted during the scanning project.
The email chain shows coordination between FBI field offices (IMD, New York) and federal prosecutors regarding the handling and digitization of sensitive evidence.
